07.01.question: What is true about creating an entity relationship diagram?

07.01.A.choice: There will be at most seven entities

07.01.C.choice: If you identify more than seven entities, analyze and combine until you have seven or less

07.01.D.choice: There will be at most seven relationships

07.01.E.choice: Entities will have at most seven attributes

07.02.question: Select all that applies to various normal forms:

07.02.A.choice: A table in 3NF is also in 2NF

07.02.B.choice: A table in 3NF is also in 1NF.

07.02.C.choice: A table in 2NF is also in 1NF.

07.03.question: Relational tables that have a single-attribute PK, are immediately in 2NF.

07.04.question: Some redundancies in a relational DB are necessary.

07.05.question: Once we have an ERD, we can be sure we have a good database structure.

07.06.C.choice: a relational table that is only 1NF

07.07.question: Foreign keys in a relational DB are an example of _____

07.07.B.choice: FKs are not redundancy at all

07.08.question: Partial dependency is a form of functional dependency.

07.09.question: Our goal with normalization is to completely eliminate redundancy.

07.10.question: Balance occurs between DFDs and ERDs when the data stores _____

07.10.A.choice: Can be equated to entities on the ERD and when entities are referred to by data stores on the DFD

07.10.C.choice: Have only one input and one output flow

07.10.D.choice: Are named the same as the relationships on the ERD

07.10.E.choice: Can be compared to ERD data flows and attributes on the ERD are included in data stores on the DFD

07.11.question: The following table is in 1NF. If we normalize this table to 2NF, how many tables in total would exist in our relational DB after normalizing to 2NF?

07.12.question: Omar has a model with 85 entities. He can do which of the following?

07.12.A.choice: Stop – he has all entities defined

07.12.B.choice: Co-validate the entities with the level 2 DFD diagrams

07.12.C.choice: Compress these into at most seven entity grouping units

07.12.E.choice: Group these into related subject areas

07.13.question: In a functional dependence, the determinant is always a single attribute.

07.14.question: In a functional dependence, the dependent is always a single attribute.

07.15.question: CRUD stands for create, read, update and delete and can be used to verify DFDs and ERDs.

07.16.question: A transitive dependency is a form of partial dependency.

07.17.question: The following table is in 1NF. If we normalize this table to 2NF, how many tables in total would exist in the resulting DB?

07.18.question: How many non-prime attributes do you see in the following dependency diagram?

07.19.question: Andrew, an analyst for PaxMedia Inc., has just learned that the business rules for a system he has been working on have changed. This means what?

07.19.A.choice: Andrew will be reassigned to a different project that is in its beginning stages

07.19.B.choice: The project will have to be scrapped and restarted

07.19.C.choice: The ERD data model will have to be put on hold while new DFD diagrams are created

07.19.D.choice: The ERD components will have to be changed

07.19.E.choice: Nothing – once the ERD data models have been drawn, they are 'frozen' for the system

07.20.question: In a relational table, when we say attribute A functionally defines attribute B (A --> B) , it means that:

07.20.A.choice: A and B must both be part of the PK.

07.20.B.choice: there is only one value of B for any given value of A.

07.20.C.choice: A and B must not be part of the PK.

07.20.D.choice: there is only one value of A for any given value of B.
